title: 113_s2417
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying after leaving office. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying after leaving office. Section 216 of this title states that individuals exceeding capacity will be punished. Section 207(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to remove references to elected Senate officers. SEC. 3. Congressional staff terms extended to 6 years. SEC. 4. Creation of lobbyists.gov for easy disclosure. SEC. 5. Lifetime ban on former members of Congress lobbying. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving that position if substantial lobbying contact occurred. A waiver can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct based on a compelling national need. Lobbying contacts must be related to pending legislative business to be considered substantial. Contacts related to pending legislative business, solicitation of funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to staff, or fundraising exceeding personal contributions are considered substantial lobbying contacts. Simple social interactions with members or staff do not qualify as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. Substantial lobbying entities must annually report to the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate any employees or individuals under contract who are former members of Congress or congressional staff with specific criteria. The filing required by this section must contain job descriptions and work experience of employees, individuals under contract, or consultants. The lobbyists.gov website will include a database of 'Substantial Lobbying Entities' for easy searchability. Law enforcement oversight will be conducted by the Clerk of the House of Representatives. The Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings of substantial lobbying entities to the District of Columbia United States Attorney for oversight. Substantial lobbying entity refers to an incorporated entity with more than 3 federally registered lobbyists. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
